description:
Ptychodera flava is a species of marine invertebrate animal belonging to the phylum Hemichordata. It is commonly known as the yellow enteropneust or the yellow acorn worm.

Ptychodera flava is a tube-dwelling, burrowing organism that can be found in shallow coastal waters of the Indo-Pacific region. It has a long, cylindrical body with a proboscis and a collar region. The body is typically yellow or orange in color, hence the common name "yellow enteropneust."

As a member of the Hemichordata, Ptychodera flava shares some morphological similarities with chordates, such as the presence of a dorsal nerve cord and gill slits. However, it lacks a true vertebral column and other key features of chordates.

Ptychodera flava feeds by extending its proboscis into the sediment and using it to collect and filter detritus and microorganisms. It plays an important role in the benthic ecosystem, contributing to the cycling of nutrients and energy within the marine environment.

The life cycle of Ptychodera flava involves a free-swimming larval stage, known as a tornaria, which eventually metamorphoses into the adult form. The species is widely distributed throughout the Indo-Pacific region, from the Red Sea to the western Pacific Ocean.
